title: Schizophrenia Recovery

content: Recovery and schizophrenia are rarely used in the same sentence. When most people think of mental health recovery, they think of issues like depression and anxiety – but not serious mental illness.
For many years, even the concept of mental health recovery wasn’t discussed. Living with schizophrenia felt alone and hopeless.

To help explain, the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) defines recovery as “a process of change through which individuals improve their health and wellness, live a self-directed life, and strive to meet their full potential.”
Despite widespread belief to the contrary, there can be recovery with schizophrenia. I wish I’d known this earlier. It would’ve been comforting and given me hope.
There’s still no cure for schizophrenia, but recovery is possible and it looks different for everyone. It takes time and work, but you can meet your full potential.

For some of us, recovery is taking care of ourselves and attending day programs. For others, it’s attending school or working. For others, it’s total remission of symptoms and the ability to work, live independently, and have a family.

content: One thing I often share about my personal mental health recovery process is that it didn’t happen overnight. It took time to get where I am today. There were times of difficulty and times of great triumph. I wouldn’t trade it for anything.
Many factors contributed to my recovery. I didn’t have to go through it alone. I had a very supportive network of family, friends, and mental health professionals who assisted me along the way.

My chances of recovery improved because I worked with a support network to create a recovery strategy. That helped me manage my symptoms, improve my quality of life, reduce my stress, and learn to monitor myself so I can identify early signs of relapse.

Accepting my diagnosis was crucial to my recovery. Without that acceptance, I wouldn’t have been able to learn about my condition and its symptoms. I was able to explain what I was experiencing. That allowed me to create a starting point for my recovery.

content: It gave me the power to learn about managing my symptoms through psychoeducation. Recovery can only really begin with proper treatment – medication and talk therapy – to achieve a level of functioning that reduces your symptoms so they don’t interfere with your daily life.

Therapy includes learning how to reality test, set goals, and regain basic life skills. I began to take care of myself by looking after my personal hygiene and grooming, creating a monthly budget, and managing my time.
Recovering these basic skills made me realize I was on a path to wellness. They helped me make further progress, too.

Once I honed the skills I learned in therapy and managed my symptoms with medication compliance, I wanted more. I started going to a day program, volunteered with the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI), enrolled in college, and went on to graduate from Saint Xavier University in Chicago.
I’ve worked in the mental health field for the last 9 years. My ability to work in the community that helped me in my recovery process gives me a sense of great purpose and pride.

content: I can’t stress enough that a successful recovery involves many parts and is best not done alone. It takes work and time. But by identifying simple goals in the beginning and maintaining medication compliance while managing symptoms, you can have a higher quality of life.
I hope that sharing my recovery process gives you hope. Recovery is possible for you, too. You’re more than your diagnosis.
While you may not have the life you want right now, your recovery story is possible and ready to be written.
